evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary pushback control lapse: active tug instructor failed to stop at TRP. NEC: The required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with; Pushback movement continued beyond TRP until blast-fence contact

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary coordination failure: challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew. NEC: Crew held divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent; No timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary environmental/marking deficiency at TRP. NEC: TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate; The marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary mechanical or control-system failure. NEC: A tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affected stopping; Corroboration exists via tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures

slot_statements.availability: The primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in hist_t3_prefinal.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified coordination failure is robust against alternative explanations, as no evidence contradicts the presence of divergent assumptions or the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings during the event.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions held by crew about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

slot_statements.availability: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation resists defeaters as it directly links the active tug instructor's failure to stop at the TRP with the procedural deviation and subsequent blast-fence contact, supported by the NEC and incident details.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause fits key features of procedural deviation where the required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with, resulting in pushback movement continuing beyond TRP until blast-fence contact.

node.statement: The primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in hist_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: The absence of warnings or challenges as reported reflects a true coordination failure
The crew's divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent contributed to the failure
defeaters: If evidence showed timely and effective challenge or stop warnings were given and understood before the TRP was exceeded
If the instructor's actions were clearly communicated and accepted by all crew members

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document that no timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues, supporting the presence of a primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among ground crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication and assumptions about stop-state

node.statement: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The tug instructor was aware of the TRP and the requirement to stop there.
No mechanical or control failures prevented stopping at the TRP.
The continued movement beyond the TRP was due to instructor control lapse rather than external factors.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to the instructor or crew, or
If mechanical or braking failures were documented that prevented stopping at the TRP, or
If communication breakdown evidence indicated the instructor was unaware of the TRP stop requirement.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H4) shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast fence, with H10 and H12 indicating the instructor was controlling pushback and expected to stop but did not, supporting the claim of a primary pushback control lapse.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiency; assumptions about instructor awareness and control are based on crew statements.

node.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions held by crew about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

assumptions: Crew communication and challenge failures are adequately represented by the provided history items
No other unreported factors (e.g., mechanical failure) contributed significantly
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or stop warnings were given and acknowledged
If TRP marking or visibility was proven to be the primary cause without coordination failure

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows crew held divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent and no timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues, supporting the root cause alignment with key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication and assumptions; no direct evidence of alternative causes

slot_statements.availability: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: There is no credible evidence or alternative explanation that effectively refutes the role of the TRP marking deficiency in causing or materially enabling the TRP miss during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal context.

node.statement: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.

assumptions: The TRP marking size and visibility as described imply inadequacy
The lack of warnings and no challenge from crew supports marking deficiency as a factor
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clear and prominent enough to be unmistakable to the crew
If there was evidence of crew attention lapse or communication failure being the primary cause instead
If mechanical control failure evidence was stronger and explained the miss

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast fence; H7 confirms the TRP location and clearance; H8 and H13 indicate the TRP marking was small and visual stop signals were insufficient, supporting the claim that the primary environmental/marking deficiency was present and observable during the phase.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew attention and communication factors; no direct measurement of marking visibility under operational conditions

node.statement: The identified coordination failure is robust against alternative explanations, as no evidence contradicts the presence of divergent assumptions or the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings during the event.

assumptions: Assuming that absence of warnings implies lack of effective challenge or stop warnings
Assuming that the statements from involved personnel are accurate and complete
defeaters: If evidence showed timely and effective challenge or stop warnings were given and acknowledged
If fault codes or mechanical tests indicated hardware malfunction causing the event

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 directly support that no effective challenge or stop warnings occurred despite cues, consistent with divergent assumptions and lack of challenge, thus supporting the robustness of the coordination failure explanation over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No contradictory evidence found; however, absence of explicit mechanical fault evidence limits absolute certainty.

slot_statements.availability: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently detectable and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase, supported by diagnostic tests and historical failure data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is robust against alternative explanations, as corroboration through tests, diagnostics, and repeat failures effectively rules out other potential causes.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The failure mode aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, including specific mechanical or control-system anomalies confirmed by corroborative evidence.

node.statement: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently detectable and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase, supported by diagnostic tests and historical failure data.

defeaters: Presence of diagnostic test results or fault codes indicating mechanical/control failure
Historical failure data showing repeatable mechanical/control malfunctions during hist_t3_prefinal phase
Direct evidence of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affecting stopping

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence of diagnostic tests or historical failure data supporting mechanical/control failure (R4). Instead, evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, H12) indicates communication and coordination issues consistent with R2, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The failure mode aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, including specific mechanical or control-system anomalies confirmed by corroborative evidence.

assumptions: Continued movement beyond TRP with engine at idle implies mechanical/control failure
No other causes (e.g., procedural deviations) fully explain the failure mode
defeaters: If evidence showed the aircraft was intentionally pushed beyond the TRP without mechanical issues
If control system diagnostics or fault codes were absent or contradicted malfunction
If environmental or marking deficiencies fully explained the event without mechanical failure

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H12 directly describe the aircraft continuing beyond the TRP and hitting the blast fence despite the tug slowing, indicating a mechanical or control failure consistent with R4.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit diagnostic or fault code evidence confirming mechanical/control failure

node.statement: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal context.

assumptions: The small size of the TRP marking implies inadequate visibility/prominence/placement.
No mechanical control failure evidence is present to contradict the marking deficiency.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was clearly visible and prominent, or if procedural deviations or communication breakdowns better explained the miss, the conclusion would change.

quotes.exact_quote: He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H13 directly supports that the TRP marking was small, indicating inadequate visibility/prominence/placement consistent with the deficiency claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited direct evidence on marking visibility and prominence; reliance on a single comment about TRP size

node.statement: There is no credible evidence or alternative explanation that effectively refutes the role of the TRP marking deficiency in causing or materially enabling the TRP miss during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.

assumptions: The small size and limited visibility of the TRP marking materially contributed to the miss.
No effective warnings or challenges were made due to marking visibility and attention limitations.
defeaters: If credible evidence showed the crew recognized and expected to stop at the TRP but continued due to procedural deviation (R1) or communication breakdown (R2), this would challenge the marking deficiency role.
If mechanical control failure evidence (R4) was corroborated, it could reduce the role of marking deficiency.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H4, H8, H10, H12, H13) shows the TRP marking was small and insufficiently prominent, with no warnings or challenges from crew despite cues, supporting the role of TRP marking deficiency in enabling the miss. Discriminators favor R3 over R1 and R2 explanations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in crew attention and communication; lack of explicit evidence of crew recognition of TRP at the moment of miss.

node.statement: The root cause fits key features of procedural deviation where the required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with, resulting in pushback movement continuing beyond TRP until blast-fence contact.

assumptions: The TRP markings were sufficiently visible and known to the tug instructor.
No mechanical failure prevented stopping at the TRP.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was inadequately visible or placed such that the instructor could not reasonably be expected to stop, or if there was a mechanical failure preventing stopping, this would change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H10, H12) shows the TRP was reached but pushback continued beyond it, indicating non-compliance with the stop point. The tug instructor was attentive but distracted (H8), and the TRP marking was small (H13), yet no warnings were given, supporting procedural deviation over marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about the adequacy of TRP visibility and marking size, but evidence favors procedural deviation.

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was physically present and not obscured or removed at the time of the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect photographic or video evidence and maintenance records to confirm the presence and condition of the TRP marking at the incident time

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was placed in a location that should have been visible to the flight crew under normal operational conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Review the TRP marking placement against standard operating procedures and cockpit sightlines to assess visibility

children_spec.statement: Environmental factors such as lighting, weather, or obstructions did not prevent the TRP marking from being visible or prominent
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze environmental data and cockpit conditions at the time to determine if visibility was impaired

node.statement: The explanation resists defeaters as it directly links the active tug instructor's failure to stop at the TRP with the procedural deviation and subsequent blast-fence contact, supported by the NEC and incident details.

assumptions: The TRP was adequately marked and visible to the tug instructor
No mechanical control failures occurred as none were reported
Communication of stop instructions was clear and understood by the instructor
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to explain the miss without instructor error
If verified mechanical or braking faults were found that caused uncontrolled movement
If communication records showed the stop state was not shared or understood before the TRP was passed

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast fence; H10 and H12 indicate the instructor was expected to stop but did not, with no communication breakdown or warnings; H8 supports that no effective warning signals were given. This directly links the instructor's failure to stop at the TRP with the procedural deviation and collision, supporting R1 over alternatives.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity about visibility or marking adequacy of the TRP and absence of mechanical failure evidence

children_spec.statement: Ground crew members were physically present and reachable during the critical time window
children_spec.test_procedure: Check logs, communications records, and personnel tracking data to confirm presence and availability of ground crew at the time of the incident

children_spec.statement: Communication devices used by ground crew were operational and functional during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and device logs to verify that radios or other communication tools were working and not malfunctioning

children_spec.statement: Ground crew had unimpeded access to communication channels necessary to issue challenges or stop warnings
children_spec.test_procedure: Review communication protocols and channel usage to determine if any blockages or restrictions prevented timely alerts

children_spec.statement: Ground crew were cognitively available and attentive to detect cues requiring challenge or stop warnings
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze crew duty schedules, fatigue reports, and situational awareness assessments to evaluate attentiveness during the event

children_spec.statement: The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify tug instructor presence and control logs or witness statements during the pushback event

children_spec.statement: The TRP stop/release point was clearly defined and reachable during the pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Check operational procedures and physical layout to confirm TRP stop point availability and visibility

children_spec.statement: The tug instructor failed to stop the pushback movement at the TRP stop/release point
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze pushback movement data and control inputs to determine if stop command was issued and ignored

children_spec.statement: Pushback movement continued beyond the TRP stop/release point until blast-fence contact occurred
children_spec.test_procedure: Review pushback path tracking and damage reports to confirm movement beyond TRP and blast-fence contact

node.statement: Ground crew had unimpeded access to communication channels necessary to issue challenges or stop warnings

assumptions: Access to communication channels implies ability to issue challenges or stop warnings
No explicit mention of technical communication failures implies channels were unimpeded
defeaters: If evidence showed communication channels were physically blocked or unavailable to ground crew
If warnings or challenges were issued but ignored or ineffective

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows ground crew had access to communication channels but did not issue challenges or stop warnings, supporting the claim of unimpeded access yet failure to challenge.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication was effectively used despite availability

node.statement: The TRP marking was placed in a location that should have been visible to the flight crew under normal operational conditions

assumptions: Small size of TRP marking implies inadequate visibility under normal operational conditions
No other evidence indicates the marking was clearly visible to the flight crew
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was large, prominent, and clearly visible to the crew under normal conditions
If crew statements or observations confirmed clear visibility of the TRP marking during pushback

quotes.exact_quote: He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H13 indicates the TRP marking was quite small, implying limited visibility/prominence, contradicting the claim that the TRP marking was placed in a location visible under normal conditions. No evidence supports good visibility; thus, the claim is contradicted.
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited direct evidence on TRP marking visibility and crew perception; reliance on indirect comment about marking size

node.statement: Environmental factors such as lighting, weather, or obstructions did not prevent the TRP marking from being visible or prominent

assumptions: The description 'quite small' implies inadequate visibility or prominence of the TRP marking.
No other evidence indicates lighting, weather, or obstructions prevented visibility.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was large, well-lit, and clearly visible without obstructions, or if crew attention lapses were clearly documented as the sole cause.

quotes.exact_quote: He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H13 directly states the TRP marking was quite small, indicating environmental/marking visibility/prominence was inadequate, contradicting the claim that environmental factors did not prevent TRP marking visibility.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in subjective assessment of marking prominence and lack of explicit lighting or weather condition details.

node.statement: The TRP marking was physically present and not obscured or removed at the time of the incident

assumptions: The statement that the TRP was 'quite small' implies it was physically present and visible but possibly less prominent
No evidence indicates the marking was obscured or removed
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was obscured, removed, or physically absent at the time of the incident
If other evidence indicated the marking was not visible or prominent enough to be noticed

quotes.exact_quote: He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H13) directly states the TRP marking was physically present but quite small, supporting that the marking was present and not obscured, thus supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in marking prominence and subjective perception of marking size

node.statement: The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation

assumptions: Presence and control inferred from seating, actions, and observations in H1, H3, H12
No mechanical failure or communication issues overriding instructor control
defeaters: If evidence showed the instructor was not in control or absent during pushback past the TRP
If mechanical failure or communication breakdown better explained the continued movement

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H3, H12) shows the tug instructor was present and actively controlling the pushback during the operation, including after the TRP was reached (H4). The continued movement beyond the TRP despite instructor control supports the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of instructor distraction level or exact control inputs; some ambiguity in attention split (H3, H12).

node.statement: Pushback movement continued beyond the TRP stop/release point until blast-fence contact occurred

assumptions: Crew recognized the TRP and expected to stop there based on training and role awareness.
No mechanical failure prevented stopping as none was reported.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or inadequately marked to the crew, or if the crew did not recognize the TRP, then R3 would be favored.
If communication records indicated the stop state at TRP was not shared or understood, supporting R2.
If mechanical faults were documented that prevented stopping, supporting R4.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H4) confirms the pushback continued beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact. The trainee (H10) and headset operator (H12) expected a stop at the TRP, indicating recognition of the TRP and expected stopping, supporting R1 over R3. The small size of the TRP marking (H13) is noted but does not explain the failure to stop given the crew's awareness.
outcome.uncertainty_source: small TRP marking size and possible attention split during pushback could introduce ambiguity, but evidence favors procedural deviation.

node.statement: Ground crew were cognitively available and attentive to detect cues requiring challenge or stop warnings

assumptions: Attentiveness includes cognitive availability to detect cues even if no challenge was issued.
Failure to challenge despite cues implies attentiveness but possibly deference or assumption of correct action by others.
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit warnings or challenges were issued and ignored, or if the crew were distracted or inattentive, this would change the assessment.
If TRP markings were so inadequate that cues were not perceivable, supporting R3 instead.

quotes.exact_quote: The instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H3, H8, H10, H12) shows ground crew were attentive but held divergent assumptions and failed to challenge or stop despite cues, supporting the claim of cognitive availability and attentiveness but ineffective challenge.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether attentiveness equates to effective challenge; assumptions and deference among crew limit clarity.

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was physically present and not obscured or missing at the time of the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check inspection and maintenance records, and conduct a site survey or review photos to confirm the presence and condition of the TRP marking

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was placed in a location that was visible and within the expected line of sight for the operator
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze site layout and operator position to verify if the marking location was within normal visibility range

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking had sufficient prominence (size, color contrast, lighting) to be noticed under the environmental conditions at the time
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate the marking’s physical characteristics and environmental lighting conditions to assess if the marking was sufficiently prominent

children_spec.statement: The marking deficiency was a plausible cause or materially enabled the TRP miss
children_spec.test_procedure: Review incident reports and operator statements to determine if the marking deficiency contributed to the TRP miss

node.statement: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is robust against alternative explanations, as corroboration through tests, diagnostics, and repeat failures effectively rules out other potential causes.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond the TRP with engine at idle indicates a mechanical/control failure rather than procedural error
Lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies no procedural intervention to prevent collision
The tug instructor’s attention split and signaling limitations did not mask a mechanical fault
defeaters: If evidence showed effective visual or procedural signals were given and ignored without mechanical fault
If tests or diagnostics ruled out mechanical/control system malfunction
If repeat failures or fault codes were absent or contradicted

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, and H12 directly document the tug and aircraft behavior consistent with a mechanical/control failure, including continued movement past the TRP despite expected stopping signals and no warnings from crew, supporting the robustness of the mechanical failure conclusion over alternative marking or procedural explanations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication and signaling effectiveness; limited direct diagnostic data

node.statement: The tug instructor failed to stop the pushback movement at the TRP stop/release point

assumptions: The tug instructor was responsible for stopping at the TRP once in control.
No mechanical failure prevented stopping as no such evidence is presented.
The TRP was visible and known to the instructor as per training and markings.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to the instructor, or
If mechanical failure prevented stopping despite instructor's intent, or
If communication breakdown caused the instructor to be unaware of the TRP stop requirement

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H4) shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast fence without stopping; trainee (H10) and headset operator (H12) observations confirm the instructor did not stop at the TRP despite expectation, supporting the claim of failure to stop.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of instructor's intent or mechanical condition; assumptions about awareness and control are inferred from observations.

node.statement: The TRP stop/release point was clearly defined and reachable during the pushback

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or physically reachable due to environmental or marking deficiencies, or if mechanical control failures were documented, this would change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 confirms the aircraft nosewheel reached the TRP and continued beyond it, indicating the TRP was defined and reachable. H7 confirms the TRP location and clearance, supporting its clear definition and reachability. H13 notes the TRP marking was small but does not negate its definition or reachability, supporting R1 over alternative explanations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: small TRP marking size (H13) introduces minor ambiguity but does not outweigh direct evidence of TRP reachability and definition.

node.statement: Communication devices used by ground crew were operational and functional during the incident

assumptions: Operational and functional communication devices imply availability and use, not necessarily effective communication
No direct evidence of device malfunction is present
defeaters: If evidence showed communication devices were non-operational or malfunctioning
If warnings or challenges had been effectively communicated and ignored
If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes rather than communication

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H8, H12) shows communication devices were operational but ineffective in preventing coordination failure; no warnings were given despite cues, supporting the claim that devices were functional but challenge/alert breakdown occurred.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in effectiveness of communication despite operational status

assumptions: The tug instructor was aware of the TRP and the requirement to stop there.
No mechanical or control failures prevented stopping at the TRP.
The continued movement beyond the TRP was due to instructor control lapse rather than external factors.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to the instructor or crew, or
If mechanical or braking failures were documented that prevented stopping at the TRP, or
If communication breakdown evidence indicated the instructor was unaware of the TRP stop requirement.
availability.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H4) shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast fence, with H10 and H12 indicating the instructor was controlling pushback and expected to stop but did not, supporting the claim of a primary pushback control lapse.
availability.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiency; assumptions about instructor awareness and control are based on crew statements.

assumptions: The TRP was adequately marked and visible to the tug instructor
No mechanical control failures occurred as none were reported
Communication of stop instructions was clear and understood by the instructor
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to explain the miss without instructor error
If verified mechanical or braking faults were found that caused uncontrolled movement
If communication records showed the stop state was not shared or understood before the TRP was passed
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast fence; H10 and H12 indicate the instructor was expected to stop but did not, with no communication breakdown or warnings; H8 supports that no effective warning signals were given. This directly links the instructor's failure to stop at the TRP with the procedural deviation and collision, supporting R1 over alternatives.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity about visibility or marking adequacy of the TRP and absence of mechanical failure evidence

assumptions: The TRP markings were sufficiently visible and known to the tug instructor.
No mechanical failure prevented stopping at the TRP.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was inadequately visible or placed such that the instructor could not reasonably be expected to stop, or if there was a mechanical failure preventing stopping, this would change the conclusion.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H10, H12) shows the TRP was reached but pushback continued beyond it, indicating non-compliance with the stop point. The tug instructor was attentive but distracted (H8), and the TRP marking was small (H13), yet no warnings were given, supporting procedural deviation over marking deficiency.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about the adequacy of TRP visibility and marking size, but evidence favors procedural deviation.

assumptions: The absence of warnings or challenges as reported reflects a true coordination failure
The crew's divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent contributed to the failure
defeaters: If evidence showed timely and effective challenge or stop warnings were given and understood before the TRP was exceeded
If the instructor's actions were clearly communicated and accepted by all crew members
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document that no timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues, supporting the presence of a primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among ground crew.
availability.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication and assumptions about stop-state

assumptions: Assuming that absence of warnings implies lack of effective challenge or stop warnings
Assuming that the statements from involved personnel are accurate and complete
defeaters: If evidence showed timely and effective challenge or stop warnings were given and acknowledged
If fault codes or mechanical tests indicated hardware malfunction causing the event
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 directly support that no effective challenge or stop warnings occurred despite cues, consistent with divergent assumptions and lack of challenge, thus supporting the robustness of the coordination failure explanation over mechanical failure.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: No contradictory evidence found; however, absence of explicit mechanical fault evidence limits absolute certainty.

assumptions: Crew communication and challenge failures are adequately represented by the provided history items
No other unreported factors (e.g., mechanical failure) contributed significantly
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or stop warnings were given and acknowledged
If TRP marking or visibility was proven to be the primary cause without coordination failure
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows crew held divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent and no timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues, supporting the root cause alignment with key features.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication and assumptions; no direct evidence of alternative causes

assumptions: The TRP marking size and visibility as described imply inadequacy
The lack of warnings and no challenge from crew supports marking deficiency as a factor
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clear and prominent enough to be unmistakable to the crew
If there was evidence of crew attention lapse or communication failure being the primary cause instead
If mechanical control failure evidence was stronger and explained the miss
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast fence; H7 confirms the TRP location and clearance; H8 and H13 indicate the TRP marking was small and visual stop signals were insufficient, supporting the claim that the primary environmental/marking deficiency was present and observable during the phase.
availability.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew attention and communication factors; no direct measurement of marking visibility under operational conditions

assumptions: The small size and limited visibility of the TRP marking materially contributed to the miss.
No effective warnings or challenges were made due to marking visibility and attention limitations.
defeaters: If credible evidence showed the crew recognized and expected to stop at the TRP but continued due to procedural deviation (R1) or communication breakdown (R2), this would challenge the marking deficiency role.
If mechanical control failure evidence (R4) was corroborated, it could reduce the role of marking deficiency.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H4, H8, H10, H12, H13) shows the TRP marking was small and insufficiently prominent, with no warnings or challenges from crew despite cues, supporting the role of TRP marking deficiency in enabling the miss. Discriminators favor R3 over R1 and R2 explanations.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in crew attention and communication; lack of explicit evidence of crew recognition of TRP at the moment of miss.

assumptions: The small size of the TRP marking implies inadequate visibility/prominence/placement.
No mechanical control failure evidence is present to contradict the marking deficiency.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was clearly visible and prominent, or if procedural deviations or communication breakdowns better explained the miss, the conclusion would change.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H13 directly supports that the TRP marking was small, indicating inadequate visibility/prominence/placement consistent with the deficiency claim.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: limited direct evidence on marking visibility and prominence; reliance on a single comment about TRP size

defeaters: Presence of diagnostic test results or fault codes indicating mechanical/control failure
Historical failure data showing repeatable mechanical/control malfunctions during hist_t3_prefinal phase
Direct evidence of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affecting stopping
availability.reasoning_summary: No evidence of diagnostic tests or historical failure data supporting mechanical/control failure (R4). Instead, evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, H12) indicates communication and coordination issues consistent with R2, contradicting the claim.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond the TRP with engine at idle indicates a mechanical/control failure rather than procedural error
Lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies no procedural intervention to prevent collision
The tug instructor’s attention split and signaling limitations did not mask a mechanical fault
defeaters: If evidence showed effective visual or procedural signals were given and ignored without mechanical fault
If tests or diagnostics ruled out mechanical/control system malfunction

defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, and H12 directly document the tug and aircraft behavior consistent with a mechanical/control failure, including continued movement past the TRP despite expected stopping signals and no warnings from crew, supporting the robustness of the mechanical failure conclusion over alternative marking or procedural explanations.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication and signaling effectiveness; limited direct diagnostic data

assumptions: Continued movement beyond TRP with engine at idle implies mechanical/control failure
No other causes (e.g., procedural deviations) fully explain the failure mode
defeaters: If evidence showed the aircraft was intentionally pushed beyond the TRP without mechanical issues
If control system diagnostics or fault codes were absent or contradicted malfunction

R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION:availab.statement: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal phase.
The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation
Pushback movement continued beyond the TRP stop/release point until blast-fence contact occurred
The tug instructor failed to stop the pushback movement at the TRP stop/release point
The TRP stop/release point was clearly defined and reachable during the pushback

R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION:defeate.statement: The explanation resists defeaters as it directly links the active tug instructor's failure to stop at the TRP with the procedural deviation and subsequent blast-fence contact, supported by the NEC and incident details.

R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION:fit_to_.statement: The root cause fits key features of procedural deviation where the required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with, resulting in pushback movement continuing beyond TRP until blast-fence contact.

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:availability.statement: The primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in hist_t3_prefinal.

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:availability:.statement: Ground crew had unimpeded access to communication channels necessary to issue challenges or stop warnings
Ground crew were cognitively available and attentive to detect cues requiring challenge or stop warnings
Communication devices used by ground crew were operational and functional during the incident
Ground crew members were physically present and reachable during the critical time window

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:defeater_resi.statement: The identified coordination failure is robust against alternative explanations, as no evidence contradicts the presence of divergent assumptions or the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings during the event.

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:fit_to_key_fe.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions held by crew about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY:ava.statement: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.
The TRP marking was placed in a location that should have been visible to the flight crew under normal operational conditions
The TRP marking had sufficient prominence (size, color contrast, lighting) to be noticed under the environmental conditions at the time
The marking deficiency was a plausible cause or materially enabled the TRP miss
The TRP marking was placed in a location that was visible and within the expected line of sight for the operator
The TRP marking was physically present and not obscured or missing at the time of the incident
Environmental factors such as lighting, weather, or obstructions did not prevent the TRP marking from being visible or prominent
The TRP marking was physically present and not obscured or removed at the time of the incident

R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY:def.statement: There is no credible evidence or alternative explanation that effectively refutes the role of the TRP marking deficiency in causing or materially enabling the TRP miss during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.

R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY:fit.statement: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal context.

R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE:availabili.statement: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently detectable and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase, supported by diagnostic tests and historical failure data.

R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE:defeater_r.statement: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is robust against alternative explanations, as corroboration through tests, diagnostics, and repeat failures effectively rules out other potential causes.

R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE:fit_to_key.statement: The failure mode aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, including specific mechanical or control-system anomalies confirmed by corroborative evidence.
